articles.headline: Dior Selects Raf Simons to Replace John Galliano
articles.snippet: Following the firing of John Galliano last year, the French label Dior switches to a low-key personality.
articles.abstract: Following the firing of John Galliano last year, the French label Dior switches to a low-key personality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The job at Dior has finally been filled.

articles.headline: Years After Acid Horror, Suicide Stirs Pakistan
articles.snippet: More than a decade after a vengeful man doused her face in acid, Fakhra Younas jumped to her death in Rome.
articles.abstract: More than a decade after a vengeful man doused her face in acid, Fakhra Younas jumped to her death in Rome.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Fakhra Younas went under the surgeon’s knife 38 times, hoping to repair the gruesome damage inflicted by a vengeful Pakistani man who had doused her face in acid a decade earlier, virtually melting her mouth, nose and ears.

articles.headline: Microsoft’s AOL Deal Intensifies Patent Wars
articles.snippet: The lofty price Microsoft paid AOL for 800 patents — $1.3 million each — reflects the crucial role patents are playing in the business and legal strategies of technology companies.
articles.abstract: The lofty price Microsoft paid AOL for 800 patents — $1.3 million each — reflects the crucial role patents are playing in the business and legal strategies of technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global gold rush in technology patents gained speed on Monday when Microsoft agreed to pay more than $1 billion for 800 patents held by AOL.

articles.headline: New Chief Selected at Avon
articles.snippet: In hiring Sherilyn S. McCoy after an extensive search, Avon appears to be making the case that it can turn around the company on its own, without help.
articles.abstract: In hiring Sherilyn S. McCoy after an extensive search, Avon appears to be making the case that it can turn around the company on its own, without help.
articles.lead_paragraph: Battered by the recession, Johnson & Johnson turned in 2009 to Sherilyn S. McCoy, a longtime executive who had joined the company as a scientist in 1982, to overhaul the company’s pharmaceutical division. It was a wrenching process that involved reorganizing the business at a time when patents on important drugs were expiring.

articles.headline: Raising the Floor on Pay
articles.snippet: As the nation’s economy slowly recovers, several states are pushing to raise the minimum wage, arguing that $7.25 an hour is too meager to live on.
articles.abstract: As the nation’s economy slowly recovers, several states are pushing to raise the minimum wage, arguing that $7.25 an hour is too meager to live on.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s economy slowly recovers and income inequality emerges as a crucial issue in the presidential campaign, lawmakers are facing growing pressure to raise the minimum wage, which was last increased at the federal level to $7.25 an hour in July 2009.

articles.headline: Obama Candidate Sketches Vision for World Bank
articles.snippet: Jim Yong Kim, now the president of Dartmouth, says there is no one résumé that is sufficient to address the wide human problems addressed by the World Bank.
articles.abstract: Jim Yong Kim, now the president of Dartmouth, says there is no one résumé that is sufficient to address the wide human problems addressed by the World Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the anthropologist and physician who is President Obama’s surprise choice to run the World Bank, does not have a detailed public record laying out his views of economic development, the bank’s central mission. He is not a development scholar nor, like previous presidents, a banker or foreign policy éminence grise.

articles.headline: Even as Violent Crime Falls, Killing of Officers Rises
articles.snippet: According to statistics compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, 72 police officers were killed in 2011, a 25 percent increase from the previous year and 75 percent rise from 2008.
articles.abstract: According to statistics compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, 72 police officers were killed in 2011, a 25 percent increase from the previous year and 75 percent rise from 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As violent crime has decreased across the country, a disturbing trend has emerged: rising numbers of police officers are being killed.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: Prosecutor in Martin Case Will Alone Determine Its Merits
articles.snippet: Angela B. Corey, who was appointed special prosecutor in the killing of Trayvon Martin, must alone determine whether to charge the man who shot the unarmed teenager.
articles.abstract: Angela B. Corey, who was appointed special prosecutor in the killing of Trayvon Martin, must alone determine whether to charge the man who shot the unarmed teenager.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Angela B. Corey, a Republican state attorney with a reputation for toughness, has decided not to seek a grand jury review of the Trayvon Martin shooting, keeping the resolution of a case that has transfixed the nation solely in her hands.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Trade Gains Put China in Quandary
articles.snippet: Exports surged last month, helping to produce an unexpected trade surplus of $5.35 billion in March, but imports grew lethargically, a warning sign for the nation.
articles.abstract: Exports surged last month, helping to produce an unexpected trade surplus of $5.35 billion in March, but imports grew lethargically, a warning sign for the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After months of weakness in overseas demand, especially from Europe, Chinese exports finally seem to be recovering. But now the country’s domestic economy is looking a little less robust.

articles.headline: Worst Loss This Year for Wall St.
articles.snippet: Wall Street notched its fifth consecutive decline on Tuesday fueled by concerns over the euro zone.
articles.abstract: Wall Street notched its fifth consecutive decline on Tuesday fueled by concerns over the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market sank deeper on Tuesday, eroding the first quarter’s blockbuster gains for a fifth straight day, as fears about the debt crisis in Europe re-emerged.

articles.headline: New Stance on Forgiving Mortgages
articles.snippet: Edward DeMarco, the regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said it might make sense for the mortgage finance companies to write down mortgage loan principal.
articles.abstract: Edward DeMarco, the regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said it might make sense for the mortgage finance companies to write down mortgage loan principal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Tuesday opened the door to forgiving some mortgage debt of homeowners who owe more than their houses are worth, as the Obama administration has recently urged.

articles.headline: Death of a Briton Is Thrust to Center of China Scandal
articles.snippet: The wife of Bo Xilai, who had been seen as one of the handful of rising leaders slated to run China, is being investigated in the killing of a businessman, Neil Heywood, last year.
articles.abstract: The wife of Bo Xilai, who had been seen as one of the handful of rising leaders slated to run China, is being investigated in the killing of a businessman, Neil Heywood, last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The mysterious death of a 41-year-old British businessman in a Chongqing hotel room late last year was thrust to the center of the biggest political scandal to hit China’s Communist Party in a generation on Tuesday, as the authorities declared the death a murder and named the wife of one of China’s most powerful men the leading suspect.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, John F. Burns and Jonathan Ansfield
